entry.title: Rolling your own fast matrix multiplication: loop order and vectorization
entry.summary: If you must multiply matrices, you should use dedicated libraries. However, we sometimes need to roll our own code. In C++, you can quickly write your own Matrix template: template <typename T> struct Matrix { Matrix(size_t rows, size_t cols) : data(new T[rows * cols]), rows(rows), cols(cols) {} T &operator()(size_t i, size_t j) { return data.get()[i â€¦ Continue reading Rolling your own fast matrix multiplication: loop order and vectorization

entry.title: Scan HTML faster with SIMD instructions: Chrome edition
entry.summary: Modern processors have instructions to process several bytes at once. Effectively all processors have the capability of processing 16 bytes at once. These instructions are called SIMD, for single instruction, multiple data. It was once an open question whether these instructions could be useful to accelerate common tasks such as parsing HTML or JSON. However, â€¦ Continue reading Scan HTML faster with SIMD instructions: Chrome edition

entry.title: This Month with Nim: October 2023 to June 2024 (It is a long month)
entry.summary:
Oolib Upgrade Author: Neo New super cool features here! Multiple constructor class Gun: var offence: int capacity = 6 price: int
proc `new`(offence: int) = self.offence = offence self.capacity = 8 self.price = 300
proc `new`(capacity: int) = self.offence = 14 self.capacity = capacity self.price = 200
# This `new()` is made from the type definition let _ = Gun.new(offence = 5, price = 6)
# 2nd one let _ = Gun.new(offence = 12)
# 3rd one let _ = Gun.new(capacity = 10)
class Sword: var offence: int price {.initial.} = 100
# made from the type definition let _ = Sword.new(8)
{.construct.} a type definition with {.construct.} are made into a class. Now that we can define a class without using class! type Shield {.construct.} = ref objeâ€¦

entry.title: A Commitment to Art and Dogs
Quickly checking whether a string needs escaping
entry.summary: In software, we often represent strings by surrounding them with quotes ("). What happens if the string itself contains quotes? We then need to escape the string. For example, the quote character (") or the backslash character (\) should be replaced by \" or \\. Most programmers are familiar with this process. Most strings do â€¦ Continue reading Quickly checking whether a string needs escaping

entry.title: Never reason from the results of a sampling profiler
entry.summary: In the quest for software optimization, a trusty companion is the sampling profiler, a tool available in most programming languages. These profilers work unobtrusively, taking snapshots of the programâ€™s state and recording the currently executing function or instruction. While profilers sound like a silver bullet for identifying performance bottlenecks, their usefulness has limitations. They excel â€¦ Continue reading Never reason from the results of a sampling profiler

entry.title: Science and Technology links (May 25 2024)
entry.summary: Artificial intelligence is far more efficient at producing content than human beings, as far as carbon emissions go. Human brains got larger by over 5% between 1930 and 1970. Replacing plastics by â€˜environment friendlyâ€™ alternatives typically results in greater greenhouse gas emissions. Prostate-specific antigen screening has only a small effect on menâ€™s risk of dying â€¦ Continue reading Science and Technology links (May 25 2024)

entry.title: Arenas and the almighty concatenation operator
entry.summary:
I continue to streamline an arena-based paradigm, and stumbled upon a concise technique for dynamic growth â€” an efficient, generic â€œconcatenate anything to anythingâ€ within an arena built atop a core of 9-ish lines of code. The key insight originated from a reader suggestion about dynamic arrays. The subject of concatenation can be a string, dynamic array, or even something else. The â€œsystemâ€ is extensible, and especially useful for path handling. Continuing from last time, the examples are in light, C-style C++. I chose it because templates and function overloading express the concepts succinctly. It uses no standard library functionality, so converting to C, or similar, should be straightforward. The core concatenation â€œoperatorâ€:
template<typename T> T concat(arena *a, T head, T tail) â€¦

entry.title: Guidelines for computing sizes and subscripts
entry.summary: Occasionally we need to compute the size of an object that does not yet exist, or a subscript that may fall out of bounds. Itâ€™s easy to miss the edge cases where results overflow, creating a nasty, subtle bug, even in the presence of type safety. Ideally such computations happen in specialized code, such as inside an allocator (calloc, reallocarray) and not outside by the allocatee (i.e. malloc). Mitigations exist with different trade-offs: arbitrary precision, or using a wider fixed integer â€” i.e. 128-bit integers on 64-bit hosts. In the typical case, working only with fixed size-type integers, Iâ€™ve come up with a set of guidelines to avoid overflows in the edge cases. Range check before computing a result. No exceptions. Do not cast unless you know a priori the operand is in range. Neverâ€¦

entry.title: Interesting Links for May 2024
entry.summary:
Here are some interesting things I recently read on the internet:

  • An Object-Oriented Language for the â€™20sğŸ›ï¸
    Adam Nelson remixes the good ideas from various modern programming languages and proposes what an object-oriented language designed for the present-time should be.

  • Ed Catmurâ€™s Triliteral esolangğŸ›ï¸
    Arthur Oâ€™Dwyer describes Triliteral, an esoteric programming language invented by prolific C++ contributor Ed Catmur, which is inspired by how words are created in Semitic languages by weaving vowels through triconsonantal roots.

  • The origin and virtues of semicolons in programming languagesğŸ›ï¸
    Nicole Tietz-Sokolskaya wades through computer science history trying to find the when and why of the wide use of the humble semicolon in many programming languages.

  • Is there a minimum viable language within imperative languages like C++ or Rust from which the rest of language can be built?ğŸ›ï¸
    Some wise Redditors discuss the minimal viable programming language that can serve as a core language for bigger imperative languages like C++. Lisp and Assembly are mentioned many times.

  • Type Checking as EvaluationğŸ›ï¸
    Dmitriy Kubyshkin explains are how type checking in statically typed programming languages is like evaluation of a secondary program in dynamically typed languages.

  • Unexplanations: query optimization works because sql is declarativeğŸ›ï¸
    Jamie Brandon explains the true reason why SQL queries are more amenable to optimizations compared to other programming languages.

  • Representing an Abstract Syntax Tree in C++: Part 1 - VariantsğŸ›ï¸
    Lesley Lai explores the different ways of representing Abstract Syntax Trees in C++.

  • The Alternative Implementation ProblemğŸ›ï¸
    Maxime Chevalier-Boisvert posits that most of the alternative implementations of programming languages are unsuccessful because they are incompatible with the vast amount of code written for the original implementations.

  • Everything You Never Wanted To Know About Linker ScriptğŸ›ï¸
    In this comprehensive guide, Miguel Young tells us everything there is to know about the art and science of linking to create executables.

  • Garbage Collection for Systems ProgrammersğŸ›ï¸
    Matt Kline argues that it is okay to use garbage collection with system programming languages because modern garbage collectors have amazing throughput.

  • You Wonâ€™t Believe This One Weird CPU Instruction!ğŸ›ï¸
    Vaibhav Sagar explored the history and use of the popcount CPU instruction.

  • When pure function lieğŸ›ï¸
    Troy Hinckley puzzles over how it is possible for pure functions to return different values in Common Lisp.

  • Why write unit tests?ğŸ›ï¸
    Henrik Jernevad lists some good reasons to unit test your programs.

  • Making Reasonable Use of Computer ResourcesğŸ›ï¸
    Vincent Foley argues that me must think about the performance of our software at the outset, not as an afterthought.

  • Recreating Historical Data Viz in 2024 using D3.jsğŸ›ï¸
    Danny Yang recreates W.E.B Du Boisâ€™s famous historical data visualizations using D3.js.
